sa8:0.3: 11-14. Past Is Impermanent, Painful, Empty, and Not Self
sa8:1.2: One time, the Buddha was staying at Anāthapiṇḍada’s Park in Jeta’s Grove of Śrāvastī.
sa8:2.1: It was then that the Bhagavān addressed the monks,
sa8:2.2: “Past and future form is [11] impermanent … [12] painful … [13] empty … [14] not self, so why wouldn’t present form?
sa8:2.3: Noble disciples thus observe them. They don’t look back to past form, don’t wish for future form,
sa8:2.4: and become free of desire for present form. They’re correctly headed toward complete cessation.
sa8:2.8: consciousness is [11] impermanent … [12] painful … [13] empty … [14] not self, so why wouldn’t present consciousness?
sa8:2.9: Noble disciples thus observe them. They don’t look back to past consciousness, don’t wishing for future consciousness,
sa8:2.10: and become free of desire for present consciousness. They’re correctly headed toward complete cessation.”
sa8:3.1: When the monks heard what the Buddha taught, they rejoiced and approved.
